title: 109_s3559
content: The Act may be cited as the "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005". It addresses fraud in connection with major disaster or emergency benefits. The "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" amends Chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code by adding a section on fraud in connection with major disaster or emergency benefits. It prohibits falsifying information or making fraudulent statements related to benefits authorized in connection with disaster declarations. The "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" imposes severe penalties for making false statements or representations in connection with disaster benefits, including fines, imprisonment for up to 30 years, or both. This applies to benefits involving major disaster or emergency declarations under the Disaster Relief Act of 1974, or related to procurement of property or services in connection with such declarations. The offense must involve interstate or foreign commerce. The "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" imposes severe penalties, including fines and imprisonment for up to 30 years, for false statements related to disaster benefits involving interstate or foreign commerce. The term "benefit" includes any valuable item provided by the government or other entities. The "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" defines "benefit" as any valuable item provided by the government or other entities, including records, vouchers, payments, money, or things of value. SEC. 3 and SEC. 4 of the Act increase criminal penalties for engaging in wire, radio, television, and mail fraud during and in relation to a presidentially declared major disaster or emergency. The amendments specify that the fraud must involve benefits authorized, transported, transmitted, transferred, disbursed, or paid in connection with the disaster or emergency. SEC. 4 amends Section 1341 of title 18, United States Code to increase criminal penalties for engaging in mail fraud during and in relation to a presidentially declared major disaster or emergency. It specifies that the fraud must involve benefits authorized in connection with the disaster or emergency. The United States Sentencing Commission is required to increase penalties for fraud or theft offenses related to major disaster or emergency declarations. They must also submit an explanation of their actions to Congress and provide policy recommendations for combating these offenses. The Sentencing Commission must ensure that sentencing guidelines reflect the seriousness of fraud or theft offenses related to major disasters, account for aggravating or mitigating circumstances, and maintain consistency with other directives and guidelines. They are also required to submit an explanation of their actions to Congress and provide policy recommendations for combating these offenses. The Sentencing Commission must create guidelines to address fraud and theft offenses related to major disasters, considering aggravating or mitigating circumstances and ensuring consistency with other directives. They must submit their actions to Congress within 30 days of the enactment of the Act. The Sentencing Commission must promptly create guidelines or amendments for fraud and theft offenses related to major disasters, following the procedures outlined in the Sentencing Reform Act of 1987. They must do so within 30 days of the Act's enactment.
